case_vignette: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 2 years! Initially, she used to misplace keys and forget her dog's name or her phone number! Now, she often forgets about what she has seen on television or read about the day before! She used to go for a walk every morning but stopped one month ago after she became lost on her way back home! Her son has prevented her from cooking because she has had episodes of leaving the gas stove oven on after making a meal! She becomes agitated when asked questions directly but is unconcerned when her son reports her history and says he is overprotective of her! She has hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia! Current medications include aspirin, enalapril, carvedilol, and atorvastatin! She is alert and oriented to place and person but not to time! Vital signs are within normal limits! Short- and long-term memory deficits are present! Her speech rhythm is normal but is frequently interrupted as she thinks of words to frame her sentences! She makes multiple errors while performing serial sevens! Her clock drawing is impaired and she draws 14 numbers!
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been increasingly forgetful over the past 2 years, struggling with misplacing keys, forgetting names and numbers, and not recalling what I've seen or read recently.
How old are you?
I am 73 years old.
Do you have any pre-existing health conditions or are you currently on any medication?
Yes, I have hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. I'm taking aspirin, enalapril, carvedilol, and atorvastatin.
Have you noticed any changes in your mood, behavior, or ability to perform daily activities?

Yes, I've become more agitated when asked questions directly and I recently stopped going for my daily walks because I got lost once. My son has also stopped me from cooking because I've left the gas stove on after use.
Is there any family history of dementia or neurological conditions?
I'm sorry, but I'm not aware of any family history of dementia or neurological conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Alzheimer's disease.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 73-year-old patient has been experiencing increasing forgetfulness over the past two years, including difficulties with misplacing keys, forgetting names and numbers, and not being able to recall recent events or readings. The patient has a medical history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia, and is currently taking aspirin, enalapril, carvedilol, and atorvastatin. Additionally, the patient has become more agitated when questioned directly and has ceased daily walks after an incident of getting lost. The patient's son has also intervened to prevent the patient from cooking, due to safety concerns with leaving the gas stove on. There is no known family history of dementia or neurological conditions.
